awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A wave attenuation technology for oyster reef restoration and small dock protection
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercialization potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is in advancing oyster reef restoration efforts by improving the understanding of oyster reef formation at the individual level and improving the resilience of waterfront infrastructure including small docks. This project will develop a technology that could improve ecosystem services and private dock protection. The socioeconomic importance of intact infrastructure and coastal protection includes maintaining property values, economic job opportunities, and supporting coastal infrastructure by minimizing erosion.  

This project is focused on a shallow water wave attenuation system that does not restrict water flow behind it and does not create sediment accretion.  This system is needed for both oyster reef restoration and the protection of small docks. Oyster reefs do not establish in areas that have been channelized and are then subjected to both boat waking and increased fetch due to the increased wave energy. The proposed system will be indexed to the water surface and will adapt to changes in water height but will necessarily be anchored to the bottom.  What is unknown in this project is how rigidly the system has to encounter oncoming waves in order to both survive extreme events and not absorb too much wave energy as to limit water flow.  The development of a nontoxic and biocompatible prototype would provide the data necessary to project both economic and hedonic valuation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a wave attenuation device for the establishment of oyster reef habitats in areas where they no longer exist. As an ancillary to the primary project, a new design for small docks was developed that would significantly increase resilience in the case of increasing storm intensity and frequency. Both designs are now patent pending.

In terms of economic impact for both oyster and dock installations the value of these designs is in the first case efficacy, and in the second surviving increasingly frequent large storm surges. Oyster reefs do not establish in areas that have been channelized and are then subjected to both boat waking and increased fetch leading to increased wave energy. The wave break technology developed by this project converts rotational wave energy into directional water flow, which oysters require to feed and establish on stable substrates.

The decking design creates a pressure relief surface that allows for continued structural integrity by small dock installations at high tides with high wave energy. The potential societal value includes all the ecosystem services and hedonic valuations currently sought by restoration attempts, and in addition to the cost and time involved for repairs of infrastructure. These costs are significant and impact property values as well as associated communities.

This innovation is a wave attenuation structure that is self-adapting to tidal and wave heights and converts rotational wave energy to directional laminar flow within designed flow velocity parameters. While wave breaks currently exist and are effective within design parameters, there is a need for self-adapting wave attenuating devices that maintain water flow in a way critically important to oyster survival and are made from biocompatible materials. Current fixed wave attenuation structures are generally designed to accrete material behind them by allowing water and entrained material passage, but significantly reducing water velocity and bulkwater flow. This is not desirable for either oyster restoration installations or small-scale docks that require water flow to maintain depth.

What has been developed by Botelmot Research, LLC is a wave attenuation device that converts the rotational wave energy of a water body into directional, laminar flow in a way that is adjustable for the site. The wave attenuation device includes one or more semi-flexible panels having a second portion inclined with respect to a first portion and a third portion thereof. The semi-flexible panels are spaced apart with respect to each other in a vertical direction. The wave attenuation device includes a plurality of support pilings for supporting one or more semi-flexible panels on a fixed bed position at the bottom of the water body. The highest point of the plurality of support pilings is located at a mean low tide height of the water body. Adjustable spaces between and below the semi-flexible panels are open to flow of water to enable delivery of food particles to oyster reefs while preventing sediment accretion.

In addition, as a separate patent pending technology is a wave resistant dock assembly associated with a dock frame and a dock body. The upper dock body surface may be flat or planar. At least one water discharge gap may be provided in the upper dock body surface. At least one water flow space may be provided in the lower dock body surface of the dock body. The water discharge gap in the upper dock body surface may communicate with the water flow space in the lower dock body surface. The water flow space may converge toward the water discharge gap. Accordingly, under high wave or storm conditions, water may flow from the body of water through the water flow space and discharge through the water discharge gap, eliminating or reducing water pressure against the dock body and reducing damage and premature wear to the dock body. The dock functions in the same way as with a traditional design but survives high wave energy from extreme storms significantly better, and at little additional cost. Installation is neither more technical nor significantly more expensive with respect to material cost and may require significantly less time for installation.


Last Modified: 02/26/2024
Modified by: Craig A Tinus
